You appear to prefer "experts" who agree with you rather than experts who practice the kind of science that is relevant to the field. Dr. Gordon was an engineer with expertise in lasers and Dr. Dyson a world-renowned technocrat. Neither studied or gained expertise in climate science. Both are admirable people until they move outside their fields.

In addition, sometimes when people get quite old they think they know more than they do outside their field. They long for the praise without the discipline.

JD from Ohio had trouble submitting this on the blog page and sent it by e-mail:

"'Vincelli: “In any field of science, peer-reviewed journals are the only primary source of research findings.'

What you state as fact is not true. Gene Gordon, a former frequent commenter on Dotearth and world renowned scientist and engineer stated:

“Peer review is a process designed to improve the quality of journal articles. It is not a stamp of approval; it doesn't guarantee that the data is accurate or complete, that the conclusions are correct, and that the author(s) are not playing games. There is an old boys club element. A good and conscientious editor learns to help the peer review process along but editors typically are volunteers, not professionals, they are busy people, and they are not typically experts in all the various subjects being published by the journal... Sometimes reviewers have fish to fry.” See comment 141 at http://community.nytimes.com/comments/dotearth.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/23/your-dot-concerns-about-climate-files/?permid=134”

See also Freeman Dyson’s comments about ““amateurs,” inventive spirits of uncredentialed brilliance” at http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/29/magazine/29Dyson-t.html?pagewanted=all
Additionally, of course, Hansenite scientists have thoroughly embarrassed science by trying to avoid disclosure of their underlying data. See http://climateaudit.org/2012/05/16/schmidts-conspiracy-theory/


JD Ohio

I believe it was Reagan's budget director who said all the supply side economics was nothing but a smokescreen for upper income tax cuts. And Bush the Elder, while he was still contesting the 1980 nomination, called supply-side and Laffer curve lunacy "voodoo economics."

A conclave of neoconservatives in a Harper's Magazine syposium laid out the strategy of "starving the beast" with one tactic being the running up of deficits such that debt servicing costs could crowd out social spending in the context of ceaseless calls for tax cuts as a panacea and portrayals of government as a wastrel.
Facts never had much to do with any of this. A fascinating Canadian survey by Ekos found that the values of the elites, particularly in the primacy put on tax cuts, were almost the opposite of the values of the Canadian people.

I worked for Canadian newspapers which fell under the ideological ownership of Conrad Black. Three main themes got dominant play: unite the right; brain drain; and tax cuts, with the ideology contaminating reporting. When favoured hard-right columnists would cite statistics about taxes contrary not only to Revenue Canada, but also to our own neocon thinktank, the Fraser Institute, directions were that copy was not to be edited. The journalistic virtues of accuracy, fairness and balance were sacrificed so that our upper class should have more while the vulnerable had less.
The public is being conned by the rich and their servants.

I keep telling myself that I'm being paranoid and there must be another explanation for the events of the last 10 years. But the evidence is there in front of my eyes, and getting harder to deny every day. The question is - why do we fall for it?

The right doesn't care about deficits? You are wrong, slightly. They care, deeply, whenever a Democrat is in the White House. As soon as they get there, deficits disappear as a cause of concern. More important matters, you see.

What is really burning the backsides of the right and the far right is that they have had 32 yrs. since Reagan won office and have failed to get any "structural" change. By that, they mean the gutting or elimination of programs that give justification to Democrats to get out of bed in the morning and run for reelection. The right sees 2012 as a do or die moment. In a matter of a year or so from now, the recession is likely to be forgotten as a major issue. Thus, they see their leverage evaporating.

What would be great for the right in America? For the country to go back into recession just when a Republican, that Romney fellow, were to take office. Then, they would have "proof" of the disastrous ways of Democrats, they could put the country through 3 or 4 yrs. of "restructuring", gut social programs to be bone and set the table for huge profits for their rich clients.

I once would have thought that no great political party in America would align itself with a national disaster, like a second deep recession, for political gain. I once believed that almost all the people in office had the welfare of the nation at heart. I was naive. I clung to childhood hopes. Even now, the level of this cynical game is hard to grasp.

Carol, this is off topic, but yesterday you asked a commenter to suggest cures for our economic mess, not to just complain. Here, briefly, are 3:

1. Get an efficient health care system like other developed countries. This would get us better care, and we would spend $1.5 TRILLION less each year.

2. Raise taxes on the Rich and real taxes on corporations. This would discourage corporations from sitting on cash and the Rich from taking obscene compensation. In turn this would encourage them to pay their workers more increasing demand and discourage them from financial speculation.

3. Have the federal government provide $1 TRILLION to promote job creation. Private business will not hire if there is low demand The money should not go for tax cuts but to states and localities to hire back teachers, cops, etc. and for projects like a new power grid and fixing roads and bridges. This will increase demand and encourage businesses to hire more further increasing demand and starting a positive feedback loop. We can afford this since we can sell 10 year bonds at negative real interest rates.

For the last 30 years America has been on the Conservative merry-go-round. I say Conservative because there are many Democrats that have aided and abetted Republicans with their supply-side economics, free market, deregulation, low tax, smaller government policies.

Starting about 6 years ago I started reading Krugman’s columns online and began to shift away from the highly biased MSM. His column along with a bevy of Progressives sites has completely exposed the Republican canards. Unfortunately, there are millions of Americans who don’t know or even care to know who Krugman is. What people do see and hear every day is the vitriol and misinformation from the Right.

I, like many others get worked up when I see these fiscal phonies running our government with no consequences for their destructive actions. We know people like Christie and Romney place their constituents (corporations, wealthy, elites) above the middle class/Main St., yet people will keep voting them into power.

30 years of Republican ideology has finally culminated in a .01 percenter running for the highest office in the world. Greed, money, power have triumphed over a weakening middle class and society in disarray.

I’ll keep reading his column, but there's little solace knowing he’s up against a well-funded machine ready to drop the hammer on the rest of us. This carnival ride has to end and when it does, I hope millions of Americans will awaken and take back what is rightfully theirs.

I see. You make up things you think Krugman would say, and then make fun of them. Very convincing.

What he actually has been saying, consistently over the years, is standard economics. When we're in a depression, good workers sit at home doing nothing, and the work they could be doing is wasted. If the government puts them to work in this situation it essentially gets something for nothing. Meanwhile companies give the government their money to hold essentially for free, just to keep it safe: there isn't enough demand for them to want to do anything else but buy treasury bonds. So the money to put the workers back to work is also free.

The situation is very different in normal times, and Krugman (and others who believe in standard economics) yell at the government for running deficits in the good times, when it actually hurts.

In response to your first paragraph, the rich fear increased taxes and increased demands to take away some of their wealth. Once you have 20 million dollars, understand, that is not enough, not nearly enough. 50 million? Now you are in the range where a private jet is always at the ready, but, still, another 50 million wouldn't hurt. There is never enough money. Or never too much. Never.

The other reason the wealthy and the far right want to gut social programs is they want to take away the basis on which Democrats have been running for reelection for the last 40 to 60 yrs. There are two generations now that have no idea how Social Security and Medicare came to be and they won't really understand the value until the programs are gone. Millions of Americans have had it pounded into their heads that taxes, not wages that are too low, are the problem, the central problem, in their lives. The idea of social responsibility and everyone paying for the common good has been set on vaporized by persistent propaganda.

Having read of most Rand's work under intense scrutiny I find that you're actually giving her too much credit. Her objectivist point-of-view doesn't take into account people with different viewpoints (very popular with neocons these days, that) or assumes that everyone who holds her Worldview meets the highest ethical standards. Both assumptions fall under the realm of fantasy. For instance, note in Atlas Shrugged that there's absolutely no reference to any sort of environmental or consumer responsilbility whereas other historical and fictional work around the time and prior to her work make mention of these issues in regards to industry and business. There's also no empathy for anyone who might not have the same demands of life, no regard for those who aren't greedy, don't desire to be rich and don't want to reinvent the wheel. Don't let me fail to mention that there's no consideration made for minorities or those that might face hardship. According to her world, everyone should be trying to become a rich, headstrong entrepeneur who answers to noone and comes out a champ at the end of the day, even your uneducated, immigrant janitor who is steadfastly inventing and building a new mop that is going to change the entire sanitation industry.

Actually Ironmike, in 2008 the Republican minority managed to get large corporate tax cuts through the legislature in exchange for temporary increase in sales tax by .25%. Those increases expired last year.
Further, taxes on the rich have consistently been cut over the last two decades, from 13.5% to 9% today.

Also, the famous Prop. 13, which cut property taxes, due to plunging home values has stripped away years of the 2% annual increase in the RATE, so 1% this year is effectively 1.02 percent next. These lost revenues are not regained if the market value of homes suddenly goes back, nope the cities and local governments are stuck with the loss, as well as the schools. The state, by law, has to backfill these losses for the schools.

Hence the deficit is due to Republican tax cuts, not Democratic overspending. Now the State is again seeking temporary increases in taxes to cover this hole.

Please explain to me how the debt and the deficit hurt us. Is public debt crowding out private borrowing? Are the "bond vigilantes" attacking our bonds as in Europe? Does it cost us a fortune to service our debt? Come on guys. Explain it.

The first two questions can easily be answered in the negative since interest are low Real interest rates are zero or negative (!). The cost of debt service is 0.8% of the GDP. I have heard for years about increasing interest rates. If we would spend now, by the time that happens, the country will have recovered.

We never paid off the debt from WWII. Here are figures for 1946 - 1973:

Federal spending increased every year but 3.

We had a deficit every year but 7.

debt 06/28/1946 269,422,099,173.26
debt 06/30/1973 458,141,605,312.09

But as a percent of GDP gross debt went from 120% to 32% and public debt went from 109% to 24%

We did it by investing in America and growing the GDP. We did it by keeping money out of the hands of the Rich which prevented speculation.

Now, compare that period with the low marginal rate periods of the 1920's and th 2000's. We had more inequality and more speculation and we fell off a cliff.

Everything said about Republican fiscal policy may be true. However, let's not forget the fact that Democratic fiscal policy is equally inept. On the one hand, even if the tax rate on the super rich would go up to 75%, our fiscal woes would not solved. This is because of the Democrats continuing solution of throwing money at every problem that we encounter. The fact is folks, we need both. We need to increase the tax rate on the rich - they won't feel the difference anyway, AND we have to scale back on a substantial level social welfare free spending. If we do both, then maybe our great-grandchildren will live in a debt free society.

However, one shouldn't forget that sometimes the fabricated images or the popular perceptions of the leaders too turn out to be an albatross-like burden around the neck of a leader, which might be true of Chris Christie's image of being a man of tough political choices also, since he can't survive along the empty shadows for long. To get out of this bind, one has to call a spade a spade at some moment of time, and the time to keep clinging on the phony fiscal prudence seems long past now.

The requirements to start a NYC company focused on media and tech really is not that difficult. In fact I have started a few businesses based in New York, and I have setup businesses in about 10 other states. New York state and New York City were no more difficult and in a few cases less so than other places we setup shop. To say that people in New York are hostile to business means to me that you clearly don't hang out with the right people because aside from a few radicals, I rarely run into anyone who has an issue with business owners. If New York City was such an awful place to start a business, people would be commuting to all the new startups in New Jersey, Connecticut, or Long Island. NYC has a lot of young, motivated, and talented people who will help create the backbone of a strong, growing economy for the future.

sorry to say, that's a rather myopic view, for far too many reasons to list. new york's validity and brilliance as a place to locate a business is self-evident.
also, your overwrought, generalized criticism doesn't apply to a multitude of businesses that may not have the issues and problems with the city that you describe.
while there may be room for improvement in the areas you mentioned, and other places may have fine attributes, the overall outlook you have regarding nyc is pretty pathetic, and simply can't be applied to all business models.
just sayin.

Nycmacguy, google New York City LLC publishing costs.  NYC is laughable for starting small business. The first question most lawyers at the firm I work for ask is "Why would you want to base a business in NYC if you didn't have to?".  They are a Park Ave law firm BTW.

Frankly, I think anyone who wants to start a new business anywhere in the state of New York (and especially in New York City) seriously ought to have his or her head examined.

I've started businesses in several states, and no where have I faced the combination of absurdly high taxes, confiscatory fees and surcharges, idiotic regulations, inept bureaucracies staffed by surly bureaucrats, multiplicative licensing / permitting / certification / registration / documentation requirements, and general hostility toward businesses in general, that characterizes the business environment in my home state of New York.

Nowhere.

Businesses that already are here generally are stuck here. There's a sort of inertia that keeps big businesses from moving, especially in sectors like banking and finance. Small businesses, on the other hand, often rely on good will among the locals that was earned over generations and can't simply be packed in a truck and moved.

But I think you have to be out of your mind to start a new business here, knowing in advance the extreme hostility toward business that New York articulates. Talented people can be found in much more business-friendly, less-confiscatory localities; and even people who presently live in New York are allowed to move across state lines, you know.

But if having a Manhattan address is really that important to these folks, then more power to them.

-LL
